title: Online onsite admission test Radio Navigation v24.3

questions.query:
The DME installation of an aircraft flying at FL430 calculates a slant range of 15 NM from a beacon with an elevation of 167 ft.

The plan range is…

 

Note: ISA condtions.
Amplitude Modulation (AM) is...

options.text: making sure the amplitude of the radio signal does not decrease with distance.

options.comment: AM is varying the amplitude of the carrier wave to transmit information.

options.text: varying the amplitude of the carrier wave to transmit information.
amplifying the amplitude of the received signal before being sent to the headset or loudspeaker.

questions.query:
When the modulation depth (M) is 100%…

  1. The amplitude of the modulation signal is the same as the amplitude of the carrier wave.
  2. The carrier wave is fully suppressed and can no longer be received.

options.text: Only statement 1 is true; statement 2 is false.
Only statement 1 is false; statement 2 is true.

questions.query: The range of an airborne based VHF-COM transmitter mainly depends on the...

options.text: elevation of the antenna of the ground based receiver.
condition of the earth surface the radio waves have to travel along.

questions.query: FM is less sensitive to atmospheric disturbances than AM because...

options.text: FM signals are not sensitive to amplitude variations.
FM uses frequencies in excess of 30 MHz.

questions.query: The Doppler effect occurs when...

options.text: direct wave and reflected wave starts to interfere.
radio signals are refracted by the the ionosphere.

questions.query: The propagation speed of radio waves is...

options.text: 300 000 km/h but only at 15 deg C.

questions.query: Pulse Amplitude Modulation (PAM) is applied in case of...
A vertical antenna has...
A vertical dipole antenna has a polar diagram in the shape of a...
The polarisation of a vertical antenna is...
The polarisation of a horizontal antenna is...
An ADF sense antenna has a polar diagram in the shape of a...

What would be the length of a monopole antenna which is suited for 1000 MHz?
The polarisation of radio waves...

options.text: may under special circumstances change from vertical to horizontal or vice versa.
is circular in case of a rotating horizontal antenna.
starts to rotate as soon as the signal leaves the antenna.

questions.query: VHF radio waves are...

options.comment: VHF radio waves are not refracted by the different ionosphere layers because of their high frequency (>30 MHz).

questions.query: Radio waves without skywaves exist...

options.comment:
Skywaves exist until 30 MHz which equals wavelengths of more than 10 m.

Therefore, no skywaves for frequencies less than 10 m.

options.text: at frequencies with wavelengths less than 10 meters.

questions.query: The skip distance (or skip zone) is...

options.text: influenced by the degree of cloud coverage of the sky.
the safe distance to a high power radio transmitter.
the ground distance where the radio station cannot be received.
depending on the altitude of the ionosphere layers.

questions.query: Radio waves that refract by the ionosphere are those with frequencies...

options.text: in the VLF, LF, MF and HF band.

questions.query:
Bonus question!

Als je deze goed hebt, mag je een andere fout beantwoorde vraag terugtrekken!

 

A radio transmitter has a frequency of 2 MHz and the transmitting power for a range of 1000 wavelengths.

If during a transmission in the night the F-layer (no E and D layers) is at an altitude of 300 km, and the critical angle of incidence is 21º, the distance of the skip zone is approximately...
The range of surface waves...

options.text: is higher during night due to the condition of the ionosphere.

questions.query: When comparing with linear (vertical or horizontal) polarised antennas, circular polarised antennas...

options.text: are less sensitive to the attitude of the aircraft.

questions.query: Regarding direction finding, a Class-C bearing is accurate within plus or minus...
When you have lost your position, you may request a [...] to receive a radio fix.
The indicator of the ground VDF equipment responds to the...

options.text: voice modulated signal transmitted by the aircraft.

questions.query: QDR is the magnetic...

options.text: bearing of an aircraft taken by a ground station.
radial of an aircraft taken by a VOR station.

questions.query:
Which of the following radio systems is used by ATC to provide ground direction finding?

  1. VDF;
  2. ADF;
  3. NDB;
  4. VOR.
When the controller provides a QDM 180 Class-A, the given bearing is within...
The transmission of a Locator NDB is...

options.text: a N0N/A3 signal with a voice ident once per minute.
a N0N/A2 signal with a reduced transmission power.
a N0N/A1 signal with a one-letter Morse ident.
a N0N signal because the signal is non-directional.

questions.query: Which antenna(s) are used when the mode switch on the ADF control panel is set to the ANT mode to improve the audio reception?

options.text: Both the sense and the loop antenna.
Nor the sense antenna, nor the loop antenna.

questions.query: Which statement is true for an airway NDB?

options.text: The range of airway NDB's is limited to the radio horizon.
The accuracy of the line of position (LOP) received from an airway NDB is less during sunrise and sunset.
The range of an airway NDB is more than the range of a Terminal VOR.

questions.query: Which of the following statements about ADF and/or NDB is correct?

options.text: The BFO is a component of the ADF.
The only purpose of the vertical sense antenna is to enable the ADF to receive the ident.
The quadrantal error is caused by disturbances in the propagation path crossing the coast.
The frequency band is limited to 190 - 450 kHz.

questions.query:
Which of the following statements regarding NDB's is correct?

  1. Locators always transmits non-directional;
  2. Radio Broadcast Stations can always be used for NBD navigation;
  3. Oceanic NDB's can never be found at land.
What is the minimum number of NDB's to take a QTF?
An important difference between an Airway NDB and a Locator NDB is...

options.text: transmission power: airway NDB's transmit more power; locator NDB's transmit less power.
radiation pattern: airway NDB's transmits non-directional; locator NDB's transmits directional.
siting: airway NDB's outside airports; locator NDB's at airports.
frequency band: airway NDB's between 190-1750 kHz; locator NDB's between 108-118 MHz.

questions.query: The accuracy of an NDB bearing is affected by...

options.text: radio noise, Doppler effect and deviation error.
precipitation static, mountain effect and turning error.
heavy snow and rain, coastal effect and dip error.

questions.query: Which of the following alternatives results in the worst ADF bearing error?

options.comment:
Correct.

TS may lead to more than 90 degrees bearing errors.

questions.query:
Given:

A small aircraft with a cruising speed of 100 kt.

The aircraft is equipped with a two-pointer RMI.

The single pointer shows the tuned NDB, and the double pointer shows the tuned VOR.

 

When the aircraft makes a smooth 360 degrees turn on a distance of 60 NM from the beacons then...

options.text: The single pointer as well as the double pointer will keep the same indication on the compassrose.
The single pointer will keep the same indication on the compass rose; the double pointer will change its indication.
The double pointer will keep the same indication on the compass rose; the single pointer will change its indication.
The indication of both pointers on the compass rose will change.

questions.query: Which statement regarding the parking position of an ADF needle is correct?

options.text: The needle is at a 90 degrees RB position.

questions.query:
Given an HSI:

  • CRS at 270;
  • CDI at the left inner dot;
  • T/F at TO.

The aircraft is on radial...
The reception of a VOT will result in an RMI indication, that is...

options.text: dependent of the position of the aircraft.

questions.query: The accuracy of the VOR is reduced by...

Given:

  • an aircraft tracks radial 315° inbound to a VOR station;
  • the drift is 5°L;
  • the relative bearing of an NDB is 60°R.

The indication on the RMI will be (dev = 0)...
In aircraft, a bearing of a VOR station can be taken by the...

Given:

  • At VOR TCK (65°13.7'N, 155°21.1'W) the magnetic variation is 24°E;
  • The DR of the aircraft is (64°10.0'N, 152°25.0'W);
  • The magnetic variation 22°E;
  • The deviation is -1°;
  • The heading on the HSI is 255°;
  • The CRS is 290° and the CDI is on the left inner dot;
  • At the moment that the TO/FR indicator changes, the course deviation bar is completely to the right.

On which radial is the aircraft at that moment?

Which of the following statements is true for a conventional airway VOR?

  1. The fixed omni-directional antenna transmits a VHF-carrier wave with the following modulations: a 30 Hz AM reference signa, and a 1020 Hz AM Ident.
  2. The rotating directional antenna transmits a VHF-carrier wave with a 30 Hz FM variable signal.
The difference between CVOR and TVOR is...

options.text: A CVOR transmits omni-directional 360 radials; a TVOR transmits non-directional 1 radial.
A TVOR sets the limits of TMA's; a CVOR sets the limits of CTA's.
A TVOR is a low power CVOR situated near aerodromes.
A CVOR is used in combination with ILS; a TVOR is used in combination with MLS.

questions.query: The 'site errors' around a VOR are...

options.text: negligible at a TVOR due to the smaller range.
not present at a CVOR due to the 'counterpoise'.
are very small due to the application of vertical polarised antennas.
smaller for a DVOR than for a CVOR due to the antenna system.

questions.query: Which two-statement answer regarding VOR is true?

options.text: The range is line-of-sight, and the transmission frequency is in the UHF-band.
The capacity of the system is unlimited, and there is no ambiguity.
The line-of-position is a radial, and the accuracy of a CVOR and a DVOR are equal.
A full-scale-deflection is five degrees, and the transmission power is the same for all kinds of VOR stations.

questions.query: System- or beacon saturation of the DME system...

options.text: can be avoided by increasing the station delay time from 50 to150 microseconds.
is solved by introducing X- and Y-channels, resulting in 252 available interrogation frequencies.
occurs when more than 90 aircraft are demanding replies from one single ground station.
occurs when the flight crew forgets to select the DME from the 'search mode' to the 'standby mode'.

questions.query: Which statement about DME squitter pulses is true?

options.text: Squitter pulses are transmitted by the ground station to makes sure the constant duty cycle is maintained.
Squitter pulses prevent the DME from overloading when the maximum amount of aircraft is reached.
Squitter pulses are pulses that are reflected by objects between ground and aircraft.
Squitter pulses are transmitted from the interrogator in the 'search' mode.

questions.query: The reason for using X- and Y-channels within DME is...

options.text: to distinct between an interrogation signal and a reply signal on the same frequency.
to have more channels avaliable than the numer of frequencies.
to assign X-channels to civil users and Y-channels to military users.
to have X-channels in the VHF-band and Y-channels in the UHF-band.

questions.query: About the airborne DME installation, it can be said that...

options.text: the DME receiver will go directly to the Search mode when it is switched on.
options.comment: No, the DME enters the search mode only when it receives DME (squitter) pulses.

options.text: in case of a "loss of lock-on", the Memory mode will be active for about 1 minute.
in the Tracking mode, the pulse repetition frequency is much lower than in the Search mode.
the interrogator can track a maximum of 90 grounds stations (transponders).

questions.query: Squitter pulses from a DME are the result of...

options.text: reception of radar pulses on the same frequency causing interference.
responding to noise if there is no maximum use by aircraft.
interrogation pulse pairs by the airborne interrogator.
reflections from objects between aircraft and ground.

questions.query: When the plan range between a DME interrogator at FL350, and a transponder at SL is 200 NM, the calculated slant range is...

options.text: not possible as this distance exceeds the designated operational coverage (DOC) range of the DME.

questions.query: The slant range correction that must be applied to a small aircraft with a DME reading of 1 NM at an altitude of 6000 ft is...
The DME installation of an aircraft flying at FL430 calculates a slant range of 15 NM from a beacon with an elevation of 167 ft. The plan range is&he...
When flying a DME arc at a plan range of 20 NM at an altitude of 24000 ft AGL, the following DME indications apply:

Which of the following DME statements is correct?

  1. Multipath protection is done in the aircraft as well as in the ground station.
  2. Loss of reply signals may be caused as a result of the constant duty cycle.

On an ILS approach chart, there is a table that shows the required 'rate-of-descent' for a number of groundspeeds in order to fly a certain glidepath.

Under which conditions can the DME groundspeed read-out be used for this purpose?

  1. ILS/DME abeam the touch down zone;
  2. VOR/DME within 5 NM in front of the runway;
  3. TACAN within 5 NM from the airport;
  4. VORTAC 5 NM behind the runway.
An ILS sensitive area is where...

options.text: ground traffic must be controlled during ILS approaches.
ground traffic is not allowed when a CAT 1 ILS is in operation.
traffic is not allowed when ILS calibration flights are in progress.
air traffic is not allowed when a CAT 3 ILS is in operation.

questions.query: A false glideslope of an ILS is the result of...

options.text: beam bends caused by large metal surfaces in the vicinity of the ILS.
atmospheric disturbances such as heavy precipitation and thunderstorms.

questions.query: The ILS critical area is...

options.text: situated in front of the Localizer and Glide path antenna; in this area no large craft are allowed during Cat-II or Cat-III approaches.
an area around the runway where no vehicles are allowed to drive, in order to keep a safe distance to landing aircraft.
an area around the LLZ as well as the GP antenna, in which the presence of aircraft or other craft causes disturbances of the ILS signal.
for an approaching B747 aircraft much larger than for a Diamond Twinstar.

questions.query: The blue outer marker signal of the ILS is...
Which statement is correct regarding ILS-indications?

options.text: The calibration of the course deviation indicator (CDI) depends on the position of the course pointer (CP).
Just before a normal glide-path (GP) intercept, the GP-pointer will have an upward deflection.
options.comment:
Correct.

The GP is intercepted from below to prevent interception of false glide slopes.

options.text: When passing the outer marker (OM), the white light will come on at a rate of 400 Hz.
At an ILS/DME the station delay is adapted in order to show the remaining distance to the end of the runway.

questions.query: ILS radio signals are characterised by...

options.text: horizontal polarisation of the localizer signal and vertical polarisation of the glide-slope signal.
a localiser range of 25 NM and a glide-slope range of 10 NM.
a paired Morse identification on the carrier of the localiser and of the glide-slope beacon.

questions.query: When the ILS signal suffers from scalloping, there are...

options.text: rapid changes or variations which can not be followed by the aircraft but are visible on the ILS indicator.
slight changes or bends which can be followed by the aircraft.
rapid changes or bends which can be followed by the aircraft.
large changes or bends which can not be followed by the aircraft.
options.comment: Scalloping are rapid variations that are visible on the ILS indicator but cannot be followed by the aircraft.

questions.query: The transmission of the ILS glidepath beacon is characterised by a...

options.text: VHF frequency modulated carrier wave with a 90 Hz AM and a 150 Hz AM navigation signal.
UHF frequency with a minimum range of 10 NM.
series of two 30 Hz signals of which the difference in depth of modulation is measured.

questions.query: The operational capacity of an ILS is limited by...

options.text: the ILS facility performance: a CAT 3 ILS can handle more aircraft than a CAT 1/2 ILS.

questions.query: Which statement on ILS critical- and sensitive areas is true?

options.text: The critical area is always smaller than the sensitive area.
The critical area extends over an area with a range of 17 NM and a width of 70 degrees; the sensitive area extends over an area with a range 25 NM and a width of 20 degrees.
In the critical area no objects are allowed; in the sensitive area objects must not exceed certain dimensions.
In the critical area objects may cause beam bends; in the sensitive area objects may cause scalloping.

questions.query: When comparing with a standard ILS-DME, a standard MLS has...

options.text: more channels and is less sensitive to multipath.

questions.query: The execution of segmented approaches with MLS is only possible if the ground installation is equipped with a...
Which statement about MLS is true?

options.text: MLS has the same number of channels as ILS.
The facility performance categories are more stringent for MLS than for ILS.
The azimuth coverage is in principle 40° on either side of the centerline.
For 3-D positioning, distance information from a DME/N is used.

questions.query: The big advantage of MLS compared to ILS is that...

options.text: MLS has a larger range in the direction of the extended centerline than ILS.
MLS has monitoring stations resulting in a better integrity than ILS.
MLS requires less antenna systems than ILS.
MLS is less sensitive for multipath signals than ILS.

questions.query: The working principle of MLS is measuring a time difference between...

options.text: two pulses: one transmitted from the elevation antenna, the other from the azimuth antenna.
the transmission of a TO-scan and the reception of a FR-scan.
the reception of a TO-scan and a FR-scan.
the interrogation pulses from the DME and the reply pulses from the AZ and EL antenna.

questions.query: MLS measures distance by...

options.text: measuring the time taken for a primary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft and back.
time measurement between a ground-based interrogator and airborne transponder.
measuring the time taken for a secondary radar pulse to travel from the MLS transmitter to the aircraft receiver.

questions.query: The MLS AZ antenna is situated...
During periods of super-refraction, radar pulses are...

options.text: scattered, loosing too much energy for a reliable return.
traveling further causing problems with the timing of the reply pulses.
attracted by the earth's surface thereby reducing their maximum range.
absorbed by the presence of moisture in the lower part of the atmosphere.

questions.query: The azimuth resolution of radar is...

options.text: independent of the frequency of the carrier wave.

questions.query: The minimum radar range is determined by the...

  • frequency 10 GHz;
  • pulse length 1 micro-second;
  • pulse interval 1235 micro-second;
  • antenna diameter 0.7 m.

For this radar it can be stated that the...

Given:

A radar has a frequency of 10 GHz and a pulse duration of 2.5 µs.

 

The number of wave periods per pulse is...
The maximum theoretical range of a radar depends on...
The maximum theoretical range of a radar is determined by...

options.text: the time between two subsequent transmission pulses.

questions.query: The azimuth resolution of radar is improved when...

options.text:
the antenna rotates faster.

dependent of the antenna diameter and independent of the frequency.

questions.query: A long-range, ground surveillance-radar has a range of approximately...
Which statement regarding ground radar in aviation is correct?

options.text: Ground radar can be a primary radar or a secondary radar.
Ground radar can be a pulse radar or a continuous wave radar.
Ground radar can be an interrogator or a transponder.
Ground radar can have a stationary antenna or a rotating antenna.

questions.query: Regarding radar, a RSR is used by ATC for...

Complete the following statement:

Airport Surface Movement Radar operates on frequencies in the [1] band with an rpm of [2] and it is [3] possible to conclude the size of the aircraft from the blip on the radar screen.
Modern ATC systems use the following display unit:

options.text: electron gun in a vacuum glass tube with a rotating timebase and a green phosphoric screen.

questions.query:
Examples of ground radar are:

  1. surface movement radar;
  2. terminal approach radar;
  3. route surveillanace radar;
  4. precision approach radar;
  5. airborne weather radar.
A long-range, ground radar has a relative...
The airborne weather radar can NOT detect...
The frequency of weather radar is...
An airborne weather radar (AWR) uses interrogation...

options.text: pulses transmitted at a random frequency to detect possible turbulent clouds.
pulse pairs in a random order to allow lock-on on its own replies.
pulses of a constant frequency, amplitude, width and rate.
pulse with a length of 3.2 cm for best reflective properties.

questions.query: The main task of the airborne weather radar is to detect...

options.text: potential turbulent clouds and to aid navigation.
ice, snow and hail with regard to ice protection.

questions.query: An airborne weather radar shows light rain in a [...] colour.
A modern airborne weather radar makes use of...

options.text: the Internet for an actual image of the weather en-route.
an Inertial Reference System (IRS) for antenna stabilisation.
a terrain database to position the weather image over a map of the underlying terrain.

questions.query: A modern weather radar with colour display shows areas with heavy precipitation in a [...] colour.
Weather radar information can be improved by...
A frequency of ~10 GHz is considered to be the optimum for use in Airborne Weather Radars because...

options.text: greater detail can be obtained from smaller water droplets at a larger range.
less power output is required in the mapping mode.
large water droplets will give good echo's and the antenna can be kept relatively small.

questions.query: SSR makes use of...

options.text: airborne antennas to interrogate the transponders of other aircraft.
metallic parts in the aircraft construction as a back-up for the PSR.
a ground based transmit/receive antenna and an airborne receive/transmit antenna.

questions.query: Which statement about SSR is correct?

options.text: SSR allows for a 3D position of the aircraft.

questions.query: Mode-S stands for...
The function of the side lobe suppressor of an SSR is...

options.text: to have less power in the side lobes and more power in the main beam.
to avoid replies to interrogations of which the control pulse is stronger than both other pulses.

questions.query:
Which of these statements on Mode-S is correct?

  1. Mode-S comes as elementary surveillance (ELS) or as enhanced surveillance (EHS).
  2. Mode-S Extended Squitter (ES) automatically transmits the position every second.
  3. Mode-S allows for selective addressing.
Which statement is correct regarding SSR Mode-S (SSR/S)?

options.text: SSR/S is a special SSR mode with 2^12 = 4096 possible codes.
SSR/S transmits the 3D position with a higher accuracy than SSR/AC.
SSR/S has a datalink capability that is also used by TCAS-II.
options.comment:
Not position, but altitude because of the 25 ft increments (SSR/S) instead of 50 ft (SSR/AC).

SSR/AC did not supply position.

questions.query: A secondary radar requires less transmission power than a primary radar power because...

options.text: the interrogation signal only has to travel outbound.
the pulse repetition frequency, pulse width and pulse amplitude are lower.

questions.query: GPS uses two transmission frequencies because...

options.text: redundancy: in case of failure of one frequency, you can use the other one.
with two frequencies, the tropospheric delay can be determined.
it enables P-code receivers to determine the ionospheric delay.
from the difference in arrival time of the signal, the receiver clock error is calculated.

questions.query: Which of the following statements on GNSS is true?

options.text: When flying from the West to the East, the GNSS has to switch over from GPS, via Galileo and GLONASS to BEIDOU.
NAVSTAR is the Russian version of the US GPS.
Global coverage is achieved by employing a SBAS.

questions.query: An eight-channel GPS receiver selects satellites based on the...
The pseudo-range to a GPS satellite can be solved by adding a...
The GPS ‘pseudo range’ is so-called for, because the...
Which statement concerning GPS is true?

options.text: For a three-dimensional position, the GPS-receiver needs at least three satellites to obtain the receiver clock error.
Three satellites give three position spheres that intersect in three points.
The C/A code is transmitted at two frequencies; the P code is transmitted at one frequency.
Each satellite transmits at least at the following two frequencies: L1 on 1227 MHz and L2 on 1575 MHz.
options.comment:
Correct.

L1 at 1227 MHz C/A code + P code;

L2 at 1575 MHz P code.

questions.query: The American GPS-NAVSTAR lacks (is missing)...

options.text: accuracy, measuring range and alerting.
accuracy, availability and integrity.
sensitivity, availability and monitoring.
tolerance, functionality and integrity.

questions.query: Where GPS uses WGS-84, does GLONASS use...

options.comment:
This is the Chinese BeiDou reference.

GLONASS uses PZ-90.

questions.query: The advantage of a GNSS receiver over a GPS receiver is...

options.text: a GNSS receiver uses two frequencies to determine the IPD (ionospheric propagation delay).
a GNSS receiver can be used worldwide.
a GNSS receiver has a more effective RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring) function.

questions.query: GPS-NAVSTAR is...
Which statement regarding GPS is correct ?

options.text: The duration of a complete cycle of the P-code is 1 microsecond.
In the SPS (Standard Position Service), use is made of only one frequency.
The PPS allows for the reception of two frequencies to estimate the tropospheric delay.
The C/A-code is encrypted in a Y-code.

questions.query: For the civil application of GPS that uses the CA code only, the following information can be retrieved...

options.text:
position: accurate 3D position,

velocity: groundspeed and true airspeed,

path: track and heading,

time: UTC and local time.

questions.query: In GPS navigation, the random error in the pseudo-range measurement that depends on the elevation mask angle is called...
The availability of the US GPS-NAVSTAR satellite navigation system is augmented through the use of...

options.text: a satellite based augmentation system such as WAAS or EGNOS.
a connection with on-board inertial navigation systems.

questions.query: Differential GPS (DGPS) provides corrections for the following error behavior...
RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring) is a technique inside the GPS-receiver to determine...
The geostationary communication satellites of Inmarsat augment GPS by, amongst others, transmitting 'GPS ranging signals' which will...

options.text: improve the position dilution of precision (PDOP) at latitudes < 60°.
options.comment:
Correct.

As Inmarsat is geostationary above the equator.

options.text: improve the vertical dilution of precision (VDOP) at latitudes > 60°.

questions.query:
GPS augmentation must improve...

  1. accuracy;
  2. integrity;
  3. availability.

The most complete answer is...
In a GBAS the VHF Data Block (VDB) supplies the aircraft with approach data plus...

options.text: corrections and integrity information for GNSS satellites in view.
meteorological information such as visibility, wind, pressure and temperature.
operational information about possible beam bends, scalloping and noise.
an update about the current weather prevailing at the airport including possible windshear.

questions.query: Which statement is true regarding differential corrections?

options.text: Differential GPS (DGPS) uses ground based beacons (VOR, DME, ILS) to improve the acuracy durimng the final approach segment.
Every standard (basic) GPS-receiver is suitable to receive DGPS-corrections by connecting a second antenna.
Within 100 NM WAAS is more accurate than LAAS.
A local area augmentation system requires less reference stations than a wide area augmentation system although the accuracy requirement may be higher.

questions.query: One of the properties of a LAAS (Local Area Augmentation System) such as GBAS, is that in the appropriate area for approach and landing...

options.text: corrections for ionospheric delay and tropospheric delay are transmitted
GPS may use GLONASS satellites to enhance the accuracy of the position fix.
the GPS altitude is augmented by a barometric altimeter.
integrity monitoring as well as differential corrections are performed.

questions.query: In a WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System)...

options.text: differential corrections are transmitted by other satellites using an HF-datalink.
position-dependent corrections on the ranges are transmitted.

questions.query: Receiver autonomous integrity monitoring (RAIM) is applied in GPS...

options.text: near aerodromes in ground stations to improve the geometry.
to reduce the PDOP in order to improve the position accuracy.
receivers in order to warn the user when a satellite does not transmit proper signals.
and in Inmarsat-satellites to enable them to function as geostationary GPS-navigation transponders

questions.query:
To support GPS, the geostationary communicstion satellites of Inmarsat will transmit...

  1. ranging signals;
  2. differential corrections;
  3. integrity messages.
The US WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System) makes use of...
GBAS signals are sent to the...
An Area navigation (RNAV) system can be best described as...

options.text: navigation with radio beacons and/or self-contained systems without the need to fly over radio beacons.
navigation using fly-by waypoints instead of fly-over waypoints.

questions.query: What can you tell about PBN being sensor-specific or not?

options.text: PBN is sensor-specific because it uses ground- or space based radio-aids to obtain its position.
PBN is sensor-specific because it can only use one radionavigation system at a time during an approach.
PBN is NOT sensor-specific because it does not have to overfly radio beacons.
PBN is NOT sensor-specific because it may use several, different navigation systems to obtain its position.

questions.query: In PBN, linear lateral performance requirements are expressed in...
The navigation aid infrastructure of PBN consists of...

options.text: the following airspaces: oceanic/remote, continental and terminal.
the RNAV system including on-board performance monitoring and alerting.

questions.query: Amongst others, which of the following RNP specifications are in use?
Which of the following statements on RNAV and RNP is correct?

options.text:
RNAV is for en-route and terminal airspace;

RNP is for approaches.

RNAV is for en-route and terminal airspace;

RNP is for oceanic/remote-, departure/arrival- and approach airspace.

RNAV is for en-route airspace;

RNP is for terminal airspace.

RNAV is for oceanic/remote airspace;

RNP is for continental airspace.

questions.query: RNAV 5 means the aircraft is...

options.text: within 5 degrees from the track to the active waypoint.
100 - 5 = 95% of the flight time on the desired track.
within 5 miles from the track to the active waypoint.

questions.query: How is the time to the active waypoint calculated?
A turn with a fixed radius during en-route performance based navigation is a...

JW193

PBN path terminator 'DF' means...
An RF-leg is a turn with a constant radius...

options.text: to connect the two parallel tracks of a holding.

questions.query: When flying an offset flight path, the flight technical error (FTE) shows...

options.comment:
When flying a (programmed) offset flight path the FTE should read zero.

When deviating from the (offset) flight path the FTE shows a number in NM.

questions.query:
TD193

What comprises the Total System Error (TSE) in PBN operations?

options.text: TSE = PDE2 + FTE2 + NSE2.
TSE = ground station error + space vehicle error + airborne equipment error.
TSE = transmitter error + propagation error + receiver error + reading error.

questions.query:
BB193

Which of the following PBN errors is mostly affected by the flying skills of the human pilot?
How can the flight-crew monitor the navigation system error (NSE)?

options.text: Make sure the sum of the ANP and the FTE does not exceed the RNP.
Watch the flight director (FD) bars on the PFD being centered.
Monitor the LOC and GP pointers on the EFIS ND.

questions.query: In case of loss of PBN capability...

options.text: abnormal and contingency procedure are to be used.
the aircraft should land at the nearest suitable airport under guidance of an other aircraft.
the flight may be continued normally, but after the flight a safety report must be filed.

questions.query: In PBN, the navigation system error (NSE) is shown as...
When the FTE is zero (0)...

options.text: the aircraft is on its intended track and the ANP is zero.
the aircraft is on the intended track but the ANP is not necessarily zero.
the ANP equals the RNP, and the FD roll bar is centered.

questions.query: In PBN, the navigation system error (NSE) is a combination of...

options.text: the path definition error (PDE) and the computing error of the FMS.
the indication error of the EFIS and the reading/interpretation error of the pilot.
the sensor error (GNSS and IRS) and the computing error of the FMS.
the path definition error (PDE) and the flight technical error (FTE).

questions.query: In PBN, the path definition error (PDE) is...

options.text: a programing error of the flight crew.
a calculation error of the flight management system (FMS).

questions.query: An RNP Approach to LNAV minima is a non-precision approach that uses...

options.text: GNSS for lateral guidance and barometric altititude for vertical reference.
LNAV for vertical guidance and VNAV for vertical reference.
Localiser for vertical guidance and glideslope for vertical reference.

questions.query: During an RNP approach, the barometric altimeter can only be used when the...

options.text: outside air temperature is within a promulgated range.
ambient pressure is within a promulgated range.
air density is within a promulgated range.

questions.query:
BB193

An RNP APCH to LNAV/VNAV minima has lateral guidance based on [1] and vertical guidance based on [2].
An approach procedure with vertical guidance (APV) is a...

options.text: Non-Precision Approach (NPA) with a Minimum Descent Altitude (MDA).
Non-Precision Approach (NPA) with a Minimum Descent Height (MDH).

questions.query: In order to fly an RNP APCH, select the approach template from a valid, and up-to-date...

options.text: internal navigation data storage device such as a FMS, which is part of the certified aircraft configuration.
external navigation data storage device such as a tablet, which is not part of the certified aircraft configuration.
external navigation data storage device such as a hard-copy booklet holding printed versions of all type of approaches.

questions.query:
The RNAV-10 specification requires at least two independent long-range navigation systems.

What is considered a LRNS?

  1. Oceanic NDB;
  2. airway VOR;
  3. DME-N;
  4. Airborne Weather Radar
  5. GNSS;
  6. INS.
Which PBN navigation aid has a standard time limitation?

options.text: The two inertial navigation systems INS and IRS.

questions.query:
TH193

The prefix 'A' in A-RNP stands for...

Hoeveel COM-antennes heeft een F35?
